Demands: Collective Ownership, Demand housing that evolve with people, adapt to climate, and foster collective life

Image_Description/\nAlt Text: A structure of small wooden rectangular pods arrayed above a larger square community structure, all supported by steal dowels embedded into the ground.
Home_Studio: The Porous Dwelling: Reimagining Housing as the Intersection of Architecture, Ecology, and Culture — University of Calgary
Tags: Cooperative housing, Shared Spaces, Co-Housing, Co-Living
Project_Description:
This collective porous dwelling concept is built upon light and modular pods that can house one or two people each, stacked atop of a central communal hub accessible to all residents of the dwelling. Inspired by Canmore’s local biking culture and love for the outdoors, the bicycle was central to the design. The communal system of living retains the advantages found in the pod design such as ease of access by bicycle and lightly touching the earth by utilizing pillars to raise the living spaces up which allows there to be no foundation. This also increases modularity and adaptability across various possible sites and number of pods. There are three key conditions of the community, dividing vertically
into public, semi-private, and private spaces. Starting from the ground, a bike pump park connects to the bike trail which invites the public to engage with the site. A platform elevator allows for cyclists to seamlessly ride in and go up into the semi-private and private spaces.
The first structure is the communal floor for residents, with sightlines from the elevator incentivizing more social interactions and informal gatherings. Above the communal floor, the rooftop garden provides a semi-private open space. Finally, the private pods are stacked at the top. Additionally, if this communal concept is not preferred by the residents of a pod, the design allows the pods to be placed individually from the communal spire, to provide an alternative form of living.
Image_1_Alt: A floor plan of the main communal area, featuring the locations of the kitchen, workshop,  theatre, washrooms, elevator, and balcony.
Image_1_Caption: Communal Floorplan
Image_2_Alt: A floor plan of the garden on top of the communal structure, featuring the garden perimeter, atrium, elevator, and water channel.
Image_2_Caption: Garden Floorplan
Image_3_Alt: A section drawing from the east elevation of the communal building.
Image_3_Caption: Community Dwelling East Section
Image_4_Alt: A section drawing from the North elevation of the communal building.
Image_4_Caption: Community Dwelling East Section
Image_5_Alt: A rendered image showing a singular private pod, set up individual of any community structure.
Image_5_Caption: Pod Cinematic Image
Image_6_Alt: A drawing of the floorplan of an individual pod, showing the divide between the private bathroom and bedroom from the semi-private kitchen, balcony, and mudroom.
Image_7_Alt: A section drawing from the North elevation of the individual pod dwelling. .
Image_8_Alt: A section drawing from the East elevation of the individual pod dwelling. .
Demands: Challenge existing zoning constraints to provide alternative housing types, density, intensification and modes of tenure, Collective Ownership, All Urban Housing Development Must Include Accessible Public Space

Image_Description/\nAlt Text: Proposed development on the existing parking garage on 20 St Andrew Street, including a residence, public cafe, community garden. The rooftop is designed to act as a public life hub for the community.
Home_Studio: Infilling affordable housing within the Kensington Market Community Land Trust — University of Waterloo
Tags: Community land trusts, Housing theory, Shared Spaces, Programmed Circulation, Towers, Agriculture and Gardening
Project_Description:
Carpark No. 68, otherwise known as the Kensington
Market Garage, is the site we chose to develop.
Situated opposite the Kensington Market Lofts and
housing commercial units on the ground floor, we
saw great potential for the parking garage to be
developed into a residential-commercial ecosystem
that acted as an extension of the lofts and the
surrounding businesses in the area. In creating
this infill project, we sought to minimise
destruction to the existing carpark structure,
which is why we chose to built around and on top of
it. One of the key features of our project is the
carpark ramp turned communal vegetable garden which
is open to both public and residents. On the
rooftop, it also houses a pickleball court, cafe,
and a shared kitchen for residents, bringing life
and vitality to the original carpark
Image_1_Alt: Concierge on Baldwin Street
Image_1_Caption: Residents Concierge on Baldwin Street. There is a mail drop-off area, a front counter and two lifts that bring residents up. This area is accessible by residents fob.
Image_2_Alt: Concierge on St Andrew’s Street
Image_2_Caption: Residents Concierge on St Andrews Street. There is a mail drop-off area, a front counter and one lift that bring residents up. This area is accessible by residents fob.
Image_3_Alt: Internal circulation, exterior glass staircase
Image_3_Caption: Exterior open staircase that allows for internal circulation within the blocks for the residents.
Image_4_Alt: Public entrance to the rooftop soaces.
Image_4_Caption: Entrance off the alleyway on Kensington Avenue for the public to get up to the rooftop garden and all the public amenities there. Lift and Stairs access point.
Image_5_Alt: POV from the alleyway off from Kensington Ave (main public entrance)
Image_5_Caption: Alleyway access for the public
Image_6_Alt: Interior view of the cafe on the first level of the center block. The cafe has full length windows on the two sides facing the rooftop area. It allows for people to get panaromic views of kensington market while enjoying food
Image_7_Alt: View of the interiors of the communal kitchen
Image_7_Caption: Double volume communal kitchen for the residents to use. There is dining spaces as well for residents to enjoy their cooking all together.
Image_8_Alt: View of the communal kitchen for the second level
Image_8_Caption: View of the communal kitchen from the walkway on the second level. The two studio units in this project is on this walkway right above the communal kitchen. The connecting bridge that connects Block A to B goes through this area
Image_9_Caption: Pickel-ball court on the rooftop space. People sitting in the cafe right across may sit and watch others playing the sport.
Image _0_Caption: Outdoor movie theatre. When movies are screened, people can sit on the platform or grass on the ramp space. Steps have been carved out for easier accessibility. When the movie is not screening, it frames the views of people in the space.
Demands: Challenge existing zoning constraints to provide alternative housing types, density, intensification and modes of tenure, All Urban Housing Development Must Include Accessible Public Space, Demand housing that evolve with people, adapt to climate, and foster collective life

Image_Description/\nAlt Text: Transit-Edge Mixed-Use Housing Prototype
Home_Studio: Home Otherwise: Architecture, Agency, and Collective Housing Futures — University of British Columbia
Tags: Cooperative housing, Housing policy, Prefabrication, Participatory Design, Shared Spaces, Co-Housing, Mixed Use
Project_Description: It is a mid-rise mixed residential-and-commercial housing typology organized as a sequence of spatial thresholds rather than a single solid object. A sloping site and a four-metre level change create two grounds: at the lower level, CRUs and a chamfered transit plaza face Lameys Mill Road and three bus stops; above, the CRU roof becomes a shared deck used by both residents and visitors. Rising from this base, an L-shaped bar on a 4×4-metre grid is wrapped by a single-loaded corridor that thick- ens into residents-only terraces and culminates in a private roof garden. From entry plaza to shared deck to neighbour terraces and rooftop, the project tests how housing at a transit corner can host civic life, everyday neighbour contact, and clear privacy, offering a precise gradient from public to semi-public to private within South False Creek.
Image_1_Alt: The project is organized as a series of thresholds rather than one big object. At north  frontage along Lameys Mill Road, the CRU and plaza are fully public, facing the bus  stops and the street. Above that, the CRU roof deck becomes a shared terrace where  residents and visitors share. Higher up, the single-loaded corridor thickens into a  sequence of residents-only terraces, a neighbour layer where residents see and look  out for each other. Behind this, the units form the fully private layer. Together, the entry  plaza, the shared terrace, the shifting terraces, and the upper roof garden choreograph  views and distances, so the building can open itself to public life at the corner while still  stepping back into clearly private territory as it rises.
Image_1_Caption: Transit-Edge Mixed-Use Housing Prototype
Image_2_Alt: The 60 units are grouped by size and shown as different colour bands—from compact studios and one-bedroom units, to three bedroom family units .
Image_2_Caption: Unit types
Image_3_Alt: On the ground floor, along the north frontage on Lameys Mill Road, there's a row of CRUs including Cafe and a small grocery
Image_3_Caption: Public edge facing the bus stops
Image_4_Alt: From L3 up , I used single-loaded corridors so each unit has cross ventilation. I thicken the corridors into a continuous band of terraces. On each floor, the line of this terrace band shifts slightly creating different pockets for planting and seating. This kind of wrap-around terrace layout turns the circulation into a lived edge, where neighbours can casually see each other, look out for each other
Image_4_Caption: Wrap-around terrace layout
Image_5_Alt: The roof of the CRUs becomes a shared terrace, a roof deck that both residents and visitors can use. It is directly connected to the public stair from the plaza, so someone can come off the bus, walk up, and sit on this deck to enjoy the view without entering the private parts of the building
Image_5_Caption: Roof Deck
Demands: Challenge existing zoning constraints to provide alternative housing types, density, intensification and modes of tenure, Demand housing that evolve with people, adapt to climate, and foster collective life

Image_Description/\nAlt Text: Axonometric showing the four prototyped buildings for the proposed site.
Home_Studio: Home Otherwise: Architecture, Agency, and Collective Housing Futures — University of British Columbia
Tags: Cooperative housing, Shared Spaces, Programmed Circulation, Flexible Spaces, Co-Housing, Co-Living, Courtyard Housing, Agriculture and Gardening
Project_Description:
This prototype tests how the district’s urban necklace can be expressed through four single 
buildings connected into one larger volume. A porous ground level stitches the upper neighbourhood of Fairview towards the waterfront, extending the sequence of outdoor rooms with shaded courtyards and green lanes. A single stair and main circulation bridge the four buildings together, creating a continuous social pathway of shared rooms. Inside, a vertical chain of communal spaces supports a diverse mix of residents. Each floor has designated private units ranging from 1-3 bedrooms which allows each floor to have a variation of inhabitants. The prototype uses timber construction, expansive balconies, and accessible roof systems which anchor the buildings in their ecological context. The result is a site specific ‘jewel’ that strengthens the larger urban necklace while generating its own micro landscape of connection.
Image_1_Alt: Sectional drawing demonstrating crucial circulation pathways between the prototyped buildings.
Image_1_Caption: South Section

Demands: Challenge existing zoning constraints to provide alternative housing types, density, intensification and modes of tenure, Collective Ownership, All Urban Housing Development Must Include Accessible Public Space, Demand housing that evolve with people, adapt to climate, and foster collective life
